physical_appearance:This is an oil on canvas painting of a scene where a group of beggars are gathered around a fire that had been set up in front of the Gadawpalin Temple
 Pagan. The palette is dull
 and stands in contrast to the bright orange-red of the fire. A road leads to the temple
 and several figures are depicted to be trekking that path. This painting is framed by a dark brown frame. The artist\u0027s signature can be found on the bottom left corner.

sgcool_label_text:Kyaw Hlaing (1914-1996) was born in Bogalay
 Myanmar. He first studied under U That Don-Kyaik Latt and became a close pupil of Ba Nyan. Upon Ba Nyan’s recommendation
 he was appointed as an art instructor at the State School of Fine Arts in Yangon
 a position he held for ten years. The name \u0027Bogalay\u0027 was often used by him to highlight the importance of his birthplace. Proficient in both oils and watercolour
 he is most known for landscapes with his characteristic use of cerulean blue and night scenes.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: Kyaw Hlaing (1914-1996) was born in Bogalay, Myanmar. He first studied under U That Don-Kyaik Latt and became a close pupil of Ba Nyan. Upon Ba Nyan’s recommendation, he was appointed as an art instructor at the State School of Fine Arts in Yangon, a position he held for ten years. The name 'Bogalay' was often used by him to highlight the importance of his birthplace. Proficient in both oils and watercolour, he is most known for landscapes with his characteristic use of cerulean blue and night scenes.
